summary: This is an FBI Daily News Briefing from July 26, 2023, summarizing a Washington Examiner article about a victim of Jeffrey Epstein who is suing the FBI for ignoring her claims for a decade. The victim, who was Epstein's first to report to authorities, and her attorney are filing a notice of claim against the agency.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the case; the victim was working for him in 1996 when the alleged incident occurred.

persons.name: Jennifer Freeman
persons.context: Attorney for the victim who is suing the FBI; she explained they are in the process of filing a notice of claim.

connections.description: The unnamed victim was working for Epstein in 1996 and was allegedly asked to give him a foot massage, which she describes as part of being kidnapped.
Jennifer Freeman is the attorney representing the victim in the lawsuit against the FBI.

events.title: Alleged incident with Epstein
events.description: The victim, while working for Jeffrey Epstein, was asked to give him a foot massage while he watched TV. She later reported being kidnapped.

events.title: Washington Examiner article published
events.description: The Washington Examiner reported on the victim's lawsuit against the FBI and her explanation for suing.

events.title: FBI Daily News Briefing
events.description: The FBI's Daily News Briefing summarized the Washington Examiner article about the Epstein victim's lawsuit.

keyFacts: A victim of Jeffrey Epstein is suing the FBI for ignoring her claims for ten years.
The victim was Epstein's first to report to authorities about his conduct.
The alleged incident occurred in 1996 when the victim was working for Epstein and was asked to give him a foot massage, which she later described as part of being kidnapped.
The victim's attorney, Jennifer Freeman, stated they are filing a notice of claim (a legal precursor) against the FBI.
The victim reported the incident to the NYPD, who directed her to call the FBI; she spoke with an FBI agent for 45 minutes.
